title: Critically Conscious Computing: Methods for Secondary Education

images.cover: |Book_Cover.png|Several applications of computing, including VR, news, robotics, information, and automation.|Computing is everywhere, for better and worse.|@jessie|
images.index: |Appendix_Index.png|A series of labeled file folders, with a miniature boy sitting a top the M's.|So many words, so little time.|@jessie|
images.search: |Appendix_WebSearch.png|A girl looking through a telescope at the stars, but the stars are nodes and edges.|What are you looking for?|@jessie|
images.media: |Book_Cover.png|Several applications of computing, including VR, news, robotics, information, and automation.|Computing is everywhere, for better and worse.|@jessie|
images.unknown: |Appendix_Unknown.png|A question mark with a globe inside and a face melted into its side, a 404 on the left, and a small person looking up to the question mark face.|Something's missing.|@jessie|

description:
Computer science (CS) is often taught has a utopian discipline, full of powerful abstractions that can transform lives and society for the better. However, as computing has reshaped every part of society in both highly visible and highly invisible ways, it has become clear that the foundational ideas in CS carry explicit values: ones of automation, replacement, standardization, centralization, and amplification. These values have positioned it as a discipline of power, and due to the ignorance with which it is often applied, one of oppression. In this book, we reconsider the technical and pedagogical foundations of CS and CS education from this lens, and offer teaching methods for secondary education that are more critically conscious than dominant CS pedagogy, with the hope of fostering a more equitable, culturally sustaining, and just future of computing. 

This book is a living document; [submit|https://github.com/amyjko/critically-conscious-computing] ideas, improvements, and corrections.
acknowledgements: Thank you to the excellent [Jessie Huynh|https://www.jessiehuynh.com] and [Ashley Wang|https://www.linkedin.com/in/ashleyewang] for sharing their creativity and design talents; they created all of the images for the book, as well as conceived of the book's visual design. Thank you to Caroline Hardin for her detailed feedback and ideas on drafts of each chapter. Our deepest thanks also to everyone who has read and shared feedback on the book, a group we expect to continue growing.

chapters.title: Introduction
chapters.image: |Chapter00_Cover_Hello.png|The phrase 'Hello World', with a boy on the left speaking through a can to a girl on the right, who is looking away.|Let's talk about computing.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Critical CS Education History
chapters.image: |Chapter01_Cover_Faces.png|Several red outline boxes, some with faces, including Charles Babbage, Alan Turing, Ada Lovelace, Seymour Papert, and many other influential people in CS history.|People make computing.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Critical CS Education Pedagogy
chapters.image: |Chapter02_Cover_Classroom.png|A teacher is in the middle of the classroom, in dialogue with students who are seated at their desks around her.|Critical CS pedagogy is about dialogue more than development.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Critical CS Education Assessment
chapters.image: |Chapter03_Cover_Feedback.png|An overhead shot of hands writing on paper with blue marks annotating a drawing.|Assessment is about more than grades, it's about learning and agency.|@jessie|

chapters.title: CS, Equity, and Justice
chapters.image: |Chapter04_Cover_Harm.png|On the left, the form of a face being analyzed by facial recognition, on the bottom, a row of men in prison jump suits against a fence, and above, the Amazon smile logo representing the sun.|Computing is as much about prisons as it is profits.|@jessie|

chapters.title: CS and Design
chapters.image: |Chapter05_Cover_Tension.png|A girl walking an enlarged rope like a tightrope, with abstract green shapes dancing in the backdrop.|Designing software is like walking a tightrope between technical and social constraints.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Encoding Intelligence
chapters.image: |Chapter06_Cover_AIApproximation.png|A faceless human face made of lines and dots with a dress color and tie.|Can machines be smart? How?|@jessie|

chapters.title: Encoding Information
chapters.image: |Chapter07_Cover_Earth.png|Earth, in a cracked chalice, whose base is rows of bits.|Bits can model anything, but not without consequences.|@ashley|

chapters.title: Computers
chapters.image: |Chapter08_Cover_Mimic.png|On the left, a child drawing a graph and on the right, an large interconnected network of lines.|Computers were human first.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Operating Systems
chapters.image: |Chapter09_Cover_PunchCards.png|A line of gray scale people entering punch cards into a machine, with a punchcard in the background.|Operating systems, before they were automated.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Programming Languages
chapters.image: |Chapter10_Cover_ProgrammingLanguages.png|Photographs of programming language inventors, each in a blue circle.|Programming languages come from people.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Control Structures
chapters.image: |Chapter11_Cover_NoChoice.png|Three boxes connected by lines with small people inside, trying to get out.|When algorithms decide, some people find they have few options.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Data Structures
chapters.image: |Chapter12_Cover_Structure.png|A Black person looks left, viewing a black cube, with a more detailed cube below, out of view.|Data is an alternate reality.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Algorithms
chapters.image: |Chapter13_Cover_Blackbox.png|Several purple cubes of different rotations with people standing on them and in them.|The mysteries of black boxes.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Abstractions
chapters.image: |Chapter14_Cover_Abstraction.png|Three faces, left to right: a detailed photo of a White man, an illustrative sketch, and a smiley face.|Removing details from ideas through abstraction can enable expression at the loss of nuance. With computing it is no different.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Artificial Intelligence
chapters.image: |Chapter15_Cover_SciFi.png|A terminator robot with a line plot running through its chest like lightning, overseeing an infinite row of tiny workers at computers.|Depending on who you are, AI can be magical or horrifying.|@ashley|

chapters.title: Programming
chapters.image: |Chapter16_Cover_Furniture.png|An Asian man measuring and cutting wood amidst sketches and assemblies of a wooden chair.|Programming is a craft like any other.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Verification and Debugging
chapters.image: |Chapter17_Cover_FixingCar.png|A women fixing a car engine that is steaming pixelated orange, with a gas canister that says DATA nearby.|Everything breaks, including software.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Tools
chapters.image: |Chapter18_Cover_Pencil.png|Depictions of sign language, feather quills, pencils, stone tablets, and other creative tools.|All creativity involves tools of some kind. The tools of code just happen to be complex and ever-changing.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Projects
chapters.image: |Chapter19_Cover_MargaretHamilton.png|Margaret Hamilton standing atop the moon with printouts of code and illustrations of rockets in the background.|As Margaret Hamilton first observed, all software projects are software engineering projects.|@jessie|

chapters.title: Conclusion
chapters.image: |Book_Conclusion.png|A Black man and a woman staring at a tablet while colored streams of technical and sociotechnical ideas flow in and out of the device.|More just computing education is ours to imagine.|@ashley|

chapters.title: Standards
chapters.image: |Appendix_Standards.png|A laptop showing code, surrounded by a ring of bits, circuits, and other related stem concepts.|There's so much to know about CS!|@ashley|

symbols.standardsBlurb: This chapter covered the concepts in the following learning standards:
symbols.csta2CS01: ,2-CS-01| Recommend improvements to the design of computing devices, based on an analysis of how users interact with the devices.| _Observe and analyze how marginalized users interact with computing devices to identify improvements or redesigns necessary for inclusion._
symbols.csta2CS02: ,2-CS-02| Design projects that combine hardware and software components to collect and exchange data.| _Design and critique projects that combine hardware and software to gather, structure, analyzem and store data._
symbols.csta2CS03: ,2-CS-03| Systematically identify and fix problems with computing devices and their components.| _Systematically identify and fix sociotechnical problems with computing devices and their components._
symbols.csta2NI04: ,2-NI-04| Model the role of protocols in transmitting data across networks and the Internet.| _Explain the role of protocols determining who can receive data across networks and the Internet, and how._
symbols.csta2NI05: ,2-NI-05| Explain how physical and digital security measures protect electronic information.| _Explain how physical and digital security measures trade usability for data protection, and who controls those measures._
symbols.csta2NI06: ,2-NI-06| Apply multiple methods of encryption to model the secure transmission of information.| _Apply multiple methods of encryption to secure data, while examining how encryption can be a tool for both safety and extortion._
symbols.csta2DA07: ,2-DA-07| Represent data using multiple encoding schemes.| _Represent data using multiple encoding schemes while accounting for their social limitations._
symbols.csta2DA08: ,2-DA-08| Collect data using computational tools and transform the data to make it more useful and reliable.| _Examine the social implications of computational data collection and analysis._
symbols.csta2DA09: ,2-DA-09| Refine computational models based on the data they have generated.| _Refine the accuracy, fairness, and bias of computational models based on data._
symbols.csta2AP10: ,2-AP-10| Use flowcharts and/or pseudocode to address complex problems as algorithms.| _Use formal and informal notations to analyze problems algorithmically and sociotechnically._
symbols.csta2AP11: ,2-AP-11| Create clearly named variables that represent different data types and perform operations on their values.| _Create clearly named variables that faithfully capture the diversity of the phenomena they represent, and perform operations on their values that account for this diversity._
symbols.csta2AP12: ,2-AP-12| Design and iteratively develop programs that combine control structures, including nested loops and compound conditionals.| _Design and iteratively develop programs that automate decisions on data, while accounting for the effects of automation on marginalized groups._
symbols.csta2AP13: ,2-AP-13| Decompose problems and subproblems into parts to facilitate the design, implementation, and review of programs.| _Decompose problems and subproblems into parts to facilitate the design, implementation, and verification of programs, while accounting for the diversity of people and contexts being supported._
symbols.csta2AP14: ,2-AP-14| Create procedures with parameters to organize code and make it easier to reuse.| _Create procedures with parameters to organize code and make it easier to reuse, while accounting for the implications of abstractions on equity, inclusion, and justice._
symbols.csta2AP15: ,2-AP-15| Seek and incorporate feedback from team members and users to refine a solution that meets user needs.| _Engage direct and indirect stakeholders in the design and refinement software projects._
symbols.csta2AP16: ,2-AP-16| Incorporate existing code, media, and libraries into original programs, and give attribution.| _Reuse code while accounting for the assumptions, biases, and values imbued by its creators._
symbols.csta2AP17: ,2-AP-17| Systematically test and refine programs using a range of test cases.| _Systematically test and refine programs using test cases that cover common and exceptional cases, especially with marginalized groups._
symbols.csta2AP18: ,2-AP-18| Distribute tasks and maintain a project timeline when collaboratively developing computational artifacts.| _Distribute tasks and maintain a project timeline without while prioritizing equity and justice over technical constraints and deadlines._
symbols.csta2AP19: ,2-AP-19| Document programs in order to make them easier to follow, test, and debug.| _Document programs in order to make their rationale easier to comprehend and audit._
symbols.csta2IC20: ,2-IC-20| Compare tradeoffs associated with computing technologies that affect people's everyday activities and career options.| _Examine power imbalances in the design of computing systems that create, amplify, and reinforce inequities and injustices in society._
symbols.csta2IC21: ,2-IC-21| Discuss issues of bias and accessibility in the design of existing technologies.| _Explain how software excludes groups marginalized by their gender, race, ethnicity, language, and ability._
symbols.csta2IC22: ,2-IC-22| Collaborate with many contributors through strategies such as crowdsourcing or surveys when creating a computational artifact.| _Collaborate with marginalized stakeholders when designing and creating a software._
symbols.csta2IC23: ,2-IC-23| Describe tradeoffs between allowing information to be public and keeping information private and secure.| _Describe individual and collective tradeoffs of surveillance capitalism._
symbols.csta3ACS01: ,3A-CS-01| Explain how abstractions hide the underlying implementation details of computing systems embedded in everyday objects.| _Explain how abstractions hide the underlying implementation, values, and biases of computing systems embedded in everyday objects._
symbols.csta3ACS02: ,3A-CS-02| Compare levels of abstraction and interactions between application software, system software, and hardware layers.| _Examine how levels of abstraction in operating systems and hardware shape and constrain what applications are created and who can use them._
symbols.csta3ACS03: ,3A-CS-03| Develop guidelines that convey systematic troubleshooting strategies that others can use to identify and fix errors.| _Develop systematic strategies that others can use to verify, audit, and fix software defects and biases._
symbols.csta3ANI04: ,3A-NI-04| Evaluate the scalability and reliability of networks, by describing the relationship between routers, switches, servers, topology, and addressing.| _Evaluate social, technical, and sociotechnical qualities of networks in terms of routers, switches, servers, topology, and addressing._
symbols.csta3ANI05: ,3A-NI-05| Give examples to illustrate how sensitive data can be affected by malware and other attacks.| _Give examples to illustrate how sensitive data can be exploited by malware, ransomware, and harassers._
symbols.csta3ANI06: ,3A-NI-06| Recommend security measures to address various scenarios based on factors such as efficiency, feasibility, and ethical impacts.| _Recommend security measures appropriate for scenarios with varying balances of power._
symbols.csta3ANI07: ,3A-NI-07| Compare various security measures, considering tradeoffs between the usability and security of a computing system.| _Compare various security measures, considering tradeoffs between the usability, security, and accessibility of a computing system._
symbols.csta3ANI08: ,3A-NI-08| Explain tradeoffs when selecting and implementing cybersecurity recommendations.| _Explain tradeoffs to who holds power to data and services when selecting and implementing cybersecurity recommendations._
symbols.csta3ADA09: ,3A-DA-09| Translate between different bit representations of real-world phenomena, such as characters, numbers, and images.| _Translate between different bit representations of real-world phenomena, such as characters, numbers, and images, accounting for the information and accessibility lost in translation._
symbols.csta3ADA10: ,3A-DA-10| Evaluate the tradeoffs in how data elements are organized and where data is stored.| _Evaluate the efficiency, equity, and justice tradeoffs in how data elements are organized and stored._
symbols.csta3ADA11: ,3A-DA-11| Create interactive data visualizations using software tools to help others better understand real-world phenomena.| _Create interactive data visualizations to help others better understand real-world phenomena and any bias or uncertainly in the data._
symbols.csta3ADA12: ,3A-DA-12| Create computational models that represent the relationships among different elements of data collected from a phenomenon or process.| _Create computational models that represent the relationships between data collected from a phenomenon or process, while making explicit the model's limitations._
symbols.csta3AAP13: ,3A-AP-13| Create prototypes that use algorithms to solve computational problems by leveraging prior student knowledge and personal interests.| _Create prototypes that use algorithms to help dismantle systems of oppression._
symbols.csta3AAP14: ,3A-AP-14| Use lists to simplify solutions, generalizing computational problems instead of repeatedly using simple variables.| _Decide whether and how to use lists to generalize computation without erasing and exceptional cases that arise from diversity._
symbols.csta3AAP15: ,3A-AP-15| Justify the selection of specific control structures when tradeoffs involve implementation, readability, and program performance, and explain the benefits and drawbacks of choices made.| _Examine the technical, social, and political consequences of different control structures._
symbols.csta3AAP16: ,3A-AP-16| Design and iteratively develop computational artifacts for practical intent, personal expression, or to address a societal issue by using events to initiate instructions.| _Create event-based, personally meaningful, software that demonstrates critical consciousnes._
symbols.csta3AAP17: ,3A-AP-17| Decompose problems into smaller components through systematic analysis, using constructs such as procedures, modules, and/or objects.| _Systematically decompose problems into procedures, modules, and/or objects, while accounting for the implications of decomposition on diversity, equity, and inclusion._
symbols.csta3AAP18: ,3A-AP-18| Create artifacts by using procedures within a program, combinations of data and procedures, or independent but interrelated programs.| _Use functions to process data while while making embedded biases in functions explicit and transparent._
symbols.csta3AAP19: ,3A-AP-19| Systematically design and develop programs for broad audiences by incorporating feedback from users.| _Design and engineer software using design methods that center marginalized and oppressed groups’ voices and needs._
symbols.csta3AAP20: ,3A-AP-20| Evaluate licenses that limit or restrict use of computational artifacts when using resources such as libraries.| _Understand software licenses as a site of power, responsibility, and accountability._
symbols.csta3AAP21: ,3A-AP-21| Evaluate and refine computational artifacts to make them more usable and accessible.| _Identify and fix design flaws in computational artifacts that exclude people because of their identities, ethnicities, and/or abilities._
symbols.csta3AAP22: ,3A-AP-22| Design and develop computational artifacts working in team roles using collaborative tools.| _Use collaboration tools to create software in teams and in partnership with affected stakeholders._
symbols.csta3AAP23: ,3A-AP-23| Document design decisions using text, graphics, presentations, and/or demonstrations in the development of complex programs.| _Document the assumptions, values, and policies behind design decisions in development of programs._
symbols.csta3AIC24: ,3A-IC-24| Evaluate the ways computing impacts personal, ethical, social, economic, and cultural practices.| _Critique how computing amplifies, centralizes, privatizes, and automates social processes in society, impacting individuals, communities, and culture._
symbols.csta3AIC25: ,3A-IC-25| Test and refine computational artifacts to reduce bias and equity deficits.| _Systematically examine software for bias, exclusion, inequity, and injustice, identifying ways to redesign it or deter its use in particular contexts._
symbols.csta3AIC26: ,3A-IC-26| Demonstrate ways a given algorithm applies to problems across disciplines| _Demonstrate ways a given algorithm impacts different groups, communitie, and disciplines in unequal ways._
symbols.csta3AIC27: ,3A-IC-27| Use tools and methods for collaboration on a project to increase connectivity of people in different cultures and career fields.| _Use collaboration tools and methods to engage diverse teams in community-based projects._
symbols.csta3AIC28: ,3A-IC-28| Explain the beneficial and harmful effects that intellectual property laws can have on innovation.| _Explain who intellectual property laws protect and who they harm._
symbols.csta3AIC29: ,3A-IC-29| Explain the privacy concerns related to the collection and generation of data through automated processes that may not be evident to users.| _Explain how organizations use software to surveil users in order to leverage their activity data for profit and power._
symbols.csta3AIC30: ,3A-IC-30| Evaluate the social and economic implications of privacy in the context of safety, law, or ethics.| _Evaluate the interaction between privacy, computing, and power._
symbols.csta3BCS01: ,3B-CS-01| Categorize the roles of operating system software.| _Explain how distinct functions within operating system software create barriers to who can access and use computers and software._
symbols.csta3BCS02: ,3B-CS-02| Illustrate ways computing systems implement logic, input, and output through hardware components.| _Explain the values underlying the binary systems of input, output, and logic._
symbols.csta3BNI03: ,3B-NI-03| Describe the issues that impact network functionality (e.g., bandwidth, load, delay, topology).| _Describe issues that impact network functionality (e.g., bandwidth, load, delay, topology, censorship, capitalism)._
symbols.csta3BNI04: ,3B-NI-04| Compare ways software developers protect devices and information from unauthorized access.| _Compare the learnability, usability, accessibility, and security of various authorization techniques._
symbols.csta3BDA05: ,3B-DA-05| Use data analysis tools and techniques to identify patterns in data representing complex systems.| _Use data analysis tools and techniques to identify patterns in data representing complex systems, while critiquing their limits and biases._
symbols.csta3BDA06: ,3B-DA-06| Select data collection tools and techniques to generate data sets that support a claim or communicate information.| _Identify and gather data to examine claims, while acknowledging the limits of data as evidence._
symbols.csta3BDA07: ,3B-DA-07| Evaluate the ability of models and simulations to test and support the refinement of hypotheses.| _Evaluate strengths and limitations of models and simulations to test hypothesis and refine theories._
symbols.csta3BAP08: ,3B-AP-08| Describe how artificial intelligence drives many software and physical systems.| _Describe how artificial intelligence can automate complex human decisions, while also encoding and amplifying bias._
symbols.csta3BAP09: ,3B-AP-09| Implement an artificial intelligence algorithm to play a game against a human opponent or solve a problem.| _Explore the limits of artifical intelligence with respect to decision making, bias, and moral reasoning._
symbols.csta3BAP10: ,3B-AP-10| Use and adapt classic algorithms to solve computational problems.| _Use and adapt classic algorithms to solve computational problems without creating new social problems._
symbols.csta3BAP11: ,3B-AP-11| Evaluate algorithms in terms of their efficiency, correctness, and clarity.| _Evaluate algorithms in terms of their efficiency, correctness, clarity, and interaction with the matrix of oppression._
symbols.csta3BAP12: ,3B-AP-12| Compare and contrast fundamental data structures and their uses.| _Compare and contrast fundamental data structures, their uses, and their limitations in representing the diversity of human identities, experiences, and knowledge._
symbols.csta3BAP13: ,3B-AP-13| Illustrate the flow of execution of a recursive algorithm.| _Explain how the flow of execution of a recursive algorithm limits its ability to respond to unexpected data._
symbols.csta3BAP14: ,3B-AP-14| Construct solutions to problems using student-created components, such as procedures, modules and/or objects.| _Write functions, classes, or other modules while documenting the effects of decomposition on direct and indirect stakeholders._
symbols.csta3BAP15: ,3B-AP-15| Analyze a large-scale computational problem and identify generalizable patterns that can be applied to a solution.| _Analyze a large-scale computational problem and identify generalizable patterns that can be applied to a solution without amplifying systems of oppression._
symbols.csta3BAP16: ,3B-AP-16| Demonstrate code reuse by creating programming solutions using libraries and APIs.| _Reuse libraries and APIs, while accounting for their embedded values, assumptions, and biases._
symbols.csta3BAP17: ,3B-AP-17| Plan and develop programs for broad audiences using a software life cycle process.| _Plan and develop programs using engineering methods that center and empower marginalized stakeholders._
symbols.csta3BAP18: ,3B-AP-18| Explain security issues that might lead to compromised computer programs.| _Explain how security vulnerabilities might lead to individual, community, and sociopolitical consequences._
symbols.csta3BAP19: ,3B-AP-19| Develop programs for multiple computing platforms.| _Develop programs for multiple computing platforms while accounting for their accessibility to people with disabilities._
symbols.csta3BAP20: ,3B-AP-20| Use version control systems, integrated development environments (IDEs), and collaborative tools and practices (code documentation) in a group software project.| _Use version control, IDEs, documentation, and collaboration tools to faciliate community-based, collaborative, iterative software design and development._
symbols.csta3BAP21: ,3B-AP-21| Develop and use a series of test cases to verify that a program performs according to its design specifications.| _Develop and use test cases to verify that a program performs according to its design specifications, as well as to external ethical and moral principles._
symbols.csta3BAP22: ,3B-AP-22| Modify an existing program to add additional functionality and discuss intended and unintended implications (e.g., breaking other functionality).| _Modify an existing program to add additional functionality and identify intended and unintended sociotechnical implications._
symbols.csta3BAP23: ,3B-AP-23| Evaluate key qualities of a program through a process such as a code review.| _Critique technical and sociotechnical qualities of a program through code review or other analytical methods._
symbols.csta3BAP24: ,3B-AP-24| Compare multiple programming languages and discuss how their features make them suitable for solving different types of problems.| _Compare multiple programming languages, examining how their creators's values and goals make them more or less suitable for different people and problems._
symbols.csta3BIC25: ,3B-IC-25| Evaluate computational artifacts to maximize their beneficial effects and minimize harmful effects on society.| _Critique the design, engineering, and use of software in society in relation to the matrix of oppression._
symbols.csta3BIC26: ,3B-IC-26| Evaluate the impact of equity, access, and influence on the distribution of computing resources in a global society.| _Examine inequities in access to computing devices and the internet and how those inequities amplify other forms of oppression._
symbols.csta3BIC27: ,3B-IC-27| Predict how computational innovations that have revolutionized aspects of our culture might evolve.| _Predict how computational innovations will shape culture, power, and equity in global society._
symbols.csta3BIC28: ,3B-IC-28| Debate laws and regulations that impact the development and use of software.| _Debate laws, regulations, and policies that impact the development, use, and impacts of software on marginalized groups._
symbols.tolerance1: ,1| Students will develop positive social identities based on their membership in multiple groups in society.| _Students will develop positive social identities based on their membership in multiple groups in society and question how those identities are reflected in software and data._
symbols.tolerance2: ,2| Students will develop language and historical and cultural knowledge that affirm and accurately describe their membership in multiple identity groups.| _Students will develop language and historical and cultural knowledge that affirm and accurately describe their membership in multiple identity groups by examining how software exludes._
symbols.tolerance3: ,3| Recognize that people’s multiple identities interact and create unique and complex individuals.| _Recognize how data and algorithms often erase people’s multiple identities._
symbols.tolerance4: ,4| Students will express pride, confidence, and healthy self-esteem without denying the value and dignity of other people.| _Students will express pride, confidence, and healthy self-esteem in what they create with code wihtout denying the value and dignity of other people._
symbols.tolerance5: ,5| Students will recognize traits of the dominant culture, their home culture and other cultures and understand how they negotiate their own identity in multiple spaces.| _Students will recognize traits of the dominant culture, their home culture, and other cultures in computing artifacts and understand how they negotiate their own identity in computing spaces._
symbols.tolerance6: ,6| Students will express comfort with people who are both similar to and different from them and engage respectfully with all people.| _Students will create data, algorithms, and other computational artifacts that respects people who are both similar to and different from them._
symbols.tolerance7: ,7| Students will develop language and knowledge to accurately and respectfully describe how people (including themselves) are both similar to and different from each other and others in their identity groups.| _Students will develop software that uses language and knowledge to accurately and respectfully describe how people (including themselves) are both similar to and different from each other and others in their identity groups._
symbols.tolerance8: ,8| Respectfully express curiosity about the history and lived experiences of others and will exchange ideas and beliefs in an open-minded way.| _Respectfully express curiosity about the history and lived experiences of others in the context of creating software for people with unfamiliar identities._
symbols.tolerance9: ,9| Respond to diversity by building empathy, respect, understanding and connection.| _Respond to diversity by engaging in community-based, inclusive software design that includes all voices in its creation._
symbols.tolerance10: ,10| Examine diversity in social, cultural, political, and historical contexts rather than in ways that are superficial or oversimplified.| _Examine inclusive software design in the social, cultural, political, and historical contexts, rather than in ways that are superficial or oversimplified._
symbols.tolerance11: ,11| Recognize stereotypes and relate to people as individuals rather than representatives of groups.| _Recognize how data and algorithms stereotype and explore how to respect people as individuals in computation._
symbols.tolerance12: ,12| Recognize unfairness on the individual level (e.g., biased speech) and injustice at the institutional or systemic level (e.g., discrimination).| _Relate how unfair experiencies with software on the individual level (e.g., inaccessible websites) emerge from injustice as the structural level (e.g., algorithms, data, and platforms)._
symbols.tolerance13: ,13| Analyze the harmful impact of bias and injustice on the world, historically, and today.| _Analyze the harmful impact of algorithmic and data bias and injustice on the world, historically, and today._
symbols.tolerance14: ,14| Recognize that power and privilege influence relationships on interpersonal, intergroup, and institutional levels and consider how they have been affected by those dynamics.| _Recognize that the power and privilege imbued into computing influences relationships on interpersonal, intergroup, and institutional levels and consider how they have been affected by those dynamics._
symbols.tolerance15: ,15| Identify figures, groups, events and a variety of strategies and philosophies relevant to the history of social justice around the world.| _Identify figures, groups, events and a variety of strategies and philosophies relevant to the computing and social justice._
symbols.tolerance16: ,16| Express empathy when people are excluded or mistreated because of their identities and concern when they themselves experience bias.| _Express empathy when software excludes or harms people because of their identities and concern when they themselves are excluded or harmed by software._
symbols.tolerance17: ,17| Recognize their own responsibility to stand up to exclusion, prejudice, and injustice.| _Recognize their own responsibility to stand up to exclusion, prejudice, and injustice when designing, engineering, and selecting software._
symbols.tolerance18: ,18| Plan and carry out collective action against bias and injustice in the world and will evaluate what strategies are most effective.| _Plan and carry out collective action against algorithmic bias and injustice in the world of computing and evaluate what strategies are most effective._
symbols.tolerance19: ,19| Make principled decisions about when and how to take a stand against bias and injustice in their everyday lives and will do so despite negative peer or group pressure.| _Make principled decisions about when and how to take a stand against algorithmic bias and injustice in their everyday lives and will do so despite negative peer or group pressure._
symbols.tolerance20: ,20| Plan and carry out collective action against bias and injustice in the world and will evaluate what strategies are most effective.| _Plan and carry out collective action against data and algorithmic bias and injustice in the world and will evaluate what strategies are most effective._
symbols.teacherHeader: ,[CSTA Teacher Standards|https://csteachers.org/page/standards-for-cs-teachers-interactive]| Original Standard| Critically Conscious Revision
symbols.teacher1a: ,1a| Apply CS practices.| _Apply CS practices in ways that center equity and justice for marginalized groups._
symbols.teacher1b: ,1b| Apply knowledge of computing systems.| _Develop critical consciousness of computing systems knowlege._
symbols.teacher1c: ,1c| Model networks and the Internet.| _Explain how the internet shapes its accessibility, access, and impact on society._
symbols.teacher1d: ,1d| Use and analyze data.| _Apply critical perspectives to the use and analysis of data to make decisions._
symbols.teacher1e: ,1e| Develop programs and interpret algorithms.| _Develop programs and interpret algorithms through an equity and justice lens._
symbols.teacher1f: ,1f| Analyze impacts of computing.| _Analyze the interaction between computing, power, oppression, and justice._
symbols.teacher2a: ,2a| Examine issues of equity in CS.| _Examine issues of equity and justice in CS._
symbols.teacher2b: ,2b| Minimize threats to inclusion.| _Create culturally responsive and sustaining learning environments for all students._
symbols.teacher2c: ,2c| Represent diverse perspectives.| _Make space for diverse perspectives, values, and assets from both students and broader society._
symbols.teacher2d: ,2d| Use data for decision-making to improve equity.| _Use data, values, and other forms of knowledge to improve equity, inclusion, and justice in teaching._
symbols.teacher2e: ,2e| Use accessible instructional materials.| _Use accessible instructional materials, programming languages, tools, and platforms._
symbols.teacher3a: ,3a| Pursue targeted professional development.| _Pursue anti-racist professional development that centers culturally responsive and sustaining pedagogy and critical consciousness._
symbols.teacher3b: ,3b| Model continuous learning.| _Learn alongside students, modeling sociotechnical humility, vulnerability, and curiosity._
symbols.teacher3c: ,3c| Examine and counteract personal bias.| _Examine, overcome, and counter both personal and structural bias._
symbols.teacher3d: ,3d| Commit to the mission of CS for all students.| _Advocate for and implement structural change in CS education capacity, access, participation, and experience._
symbols.teacher3e: ,3e| Leverage community resources.| _Engage communities of practice and their resources, while understanding their values and who they intend serve._
symbols.teacher3f: ,3f| Participate in CS professional learning communities.| _Create, support, enrich, and sustain diverse CS professional learning communities._
symbols.teacher4a: ,4a| Analyze CS curricula.| _Critically examine and adapt CS curricula._
symbols.teacher4b: ,4b| Develop standards-aligned learning experiences.| _Develop learning experiences that account for standards and their limitations._
symbols.teacher4c: ,4c| Design inclusive learning experiences.| _Design culturally responsive and sustaining learning experiences that advance justice._
symbols.teacher4d: ,4d| Build connections between CS and other disciplines.| _Identify authentic integration points between CS and other disciplines._
symbols.teacher4e: ,4e| Plan projects that have personal meaning to students.| _Situate CS learning in students’ identities, values, goals, and communities._
symbols.teacher4f: ,4f| Plan instruction to foster student understanding.| _Co-construct learning and assessment to foster student interest, identity, and agency._
symbols.teacher4g: ,4g| Inform instruction through assessment.| _Co-design culturally responsive, participatory, and educative formative assessments to support learning._
symbols.teacher5a: ,5a| Use inquiry to faciliate student learning.| _Use inquiry and discourse to faciliate students' critical consciousness._
symbols.teacher5b: ,5b| Cultivate a positive classroom climate.| _Ensure all students feel safe, supported, valued, and heard._
symbols.teacher5c: ,5c| Promote student self-efficacy.| _Center student agency, assets, values, and culture._
symbols.teacher5d: ,5d| Support student collaboration.| _Center student collaboration and discourse to foster critical consciousness._
symbols.teacher5e: ,5e| Encourage student communication.| _Encourage student communication, reflection, writing, and speaking about CS equity and justice._
symbols.teacher5f: ,5f| Guide students’ use of feedback.| _Guide students to both seek and learn from feedback, as well provide it to those with power._

algo.definition: A precise, unambiguous process for solving a problem, written by people and often performed by a computer.

automate.definition: To replace human labor with the labor of human-made tools and machinery, including computers.

software.definition: Apps, websites, and other products and services that people use on computers, laptops, tablets, smartphones, and other digital devices that have computers in them.

computer.definition: Physical hardware that receives input, stores and processes data, and produces output. Examples include consumer devices like desktop computers, tablets, smartphones, but also less obvious devices that embed computers, like cars, kitchen appliances, and smart home devices such as smart speakers.

cs.definition: The academic discipline and community that studies both human and technical aspects of computer use, computational thinking, programs, programming, software, and software engineering.

computerscientist.definition: Anyone who studied or studies computer science.

criticalcon.definition: Awareness of the systems, values, norms, and processes that limit and potentially oppress one's life and community.

lang.definition: A notational user interface for telling computers what we want them to compute at some later point in the future.

neolib.definition: A political stance that favors free-market capitalism, deregulation, and small government over collective approaches to social progress.
